Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I was in the kitchen, kneading dough for my granddaughter’s favorite dumplings, when my daughter called from the hospital. Her voice trembled—my son-in-law had collapsed, and she needed me to watch the kids right away. My heart lurched; I could hear the children’s anxious voices in the background. I wiped my hands, ready to rush out the door, when my phone buzzed again. It was the legislative aide I’d been trying to reach for weeks. “I have ten minutes now to discuss the bill,” she said briskly. This was the moment I’d been waiting for, a chance to push for the policy changes I’d fought so hard for. But my family needed me, right now, in a way only a grandmother could be there. I stood frozen, phone in hand, torn between the urgent needs of my family and the rare opportunity to make a difference for so many others. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which call to answer first.
